project.teaser: NET-Fuels develops a novel pathway to produce carbon-negative biofuels from low value biogenic residues (such as digestate, calamity wood, pruning) through a combination of thermochemical conversion, separation of hydrogen from the syngas, oxy-fuel combustion of the tail gas...
project.objective: NET-Fuels develops a novel pathway to produce carbon-negative biofuels from low value biogenic residues (such as digestate, calamity wood, pruning) through a combination of thermochemical conversion, separation of hydrogen from the syngas, oxy-fuel combustion of the tail gas, bio-electrochemical conversion of CO2 into methane and carbon sequestration in the biochar. The process will also generate as an additional product a biofuel intermediary (high quality pyrolysis oil) which has proven conversion route into drop-in fuels. The project will take the integrated process to TRL 5, providing a platform (in terms of technical feasibility, economic performance, and environmental and social sustainability) for further demonstration and validation projects. In doing so it brings together a consortium of internationally recognized experts in biomass thermochemical conversion, bioreactors design, environmental sustainability and life cycle analysis, dynamic modelling, biochar utilisation, economic analysis and business case development and dedicated outreach, public engagement, and social sustainability analysis. The Net-Fuels system will be able to deliver 25 Mtoe of advanced biofuels in 2030 (7% share of the transport fuel consumption), if exploiting between one third and one fourth of the total pool of available feedstock listed in Part A of Annex IX in Europe. In correspondence of such objective, NET-Fuels will ensure 110 Mt of CO2 of net negative emission.
project.title: Increasing biomass conversion efficiency to carbon-negative sustainable biofuels by combination of thermal and bio-electrochemical processes
project.keywords: Advanced Biofuels, Biochar, Bio-Electrochemical Methanation, Carbon Capture and Utilisation, Pyrolysis, Oxy-fuel combustion

webItem.title: Filling the tank
webItem.alternativeText: An illustration of the contributions made by each source to the overall goal of 35 billion cubic metres of biomethane production, rendered as liquid levels in a large cylindrical gas tower.

webItem.title: Fuelling innovation
webItem.alternativeText: An illustration showing how the various elements support biomethane production. Artificial photosynthesis supplies the gas network directly. Wood biomass is gasified and sent to the gas network. Waste waters and organic matter feed the anaerobic digester, which produces biogas that is refined to biomethane before being injected into the gas network. Waste from the city, including CO2, is returned to the anaerobic digester.

webItem.title: Investing in a greener future
webItem.alternativeText: An illustration showing the value of projects in millions of euro, arranged by funding stream. Coordination and Support Actions include Bin2Grid (0.71), BiogasAction (2.0), BIOSURF (1.87), DiBiCoo (3), ISAAC (1.48), ISABEL (1.9) and REGATRACE (3). Research and Innovation Actions include CarbonNeutralLNG (3.31), CRONUS (4.39), DESIRED (3.06), FlexSNG (4.23), NET-Fuels (4.50) and PRODIGIO (2.45). Innovation Actions include BIOMETHAVERSE (9.87), HYFUELUP (10.29), METHAREN (10.36) and SEMPRE-BIO (11.75).

category.title: Projects Information Pack
category.description: Article: Selections of projects in their early stages focusing on a specific research theme

article.teaser: Europe’s energy security is under pressure from rising costs, climate change, domestic and international energy policy, and conflict. Biomethane – natural gas produced from renewable sources such as municipal and agricultural waste – offers a reliable, drop-in fuel that can meet the energy needs of citizens. This Projects Info Pack showcases the research being carried out to grow Europe’s biomethane industry, boosting energy security and helping to deliver on the EU’s ambitions for a competitive, low-carbon economy.

category.title: Project description
category.description: Article: description of linked project written by editorial team

article.title: Innovative biomethane to support Europe’s energy independence
article.teaser: A new Projects Info Pack from CORDIS highlights the ongoing research helping to deliver REPowerEU’s goal of ending reliance on Russian gas imports by 2030 and accelerating Europe’s transition to a clean energy system.

result.title: Website and project branding
result.description: A project brand will be developed including a logo and a corporate design identity as regards fonts colours and style which will be used to generate all branded project material eg website publications document and PPT templates etc Task 61

result.title: Dissemination, exploitation and communication plan
result.description: The Dissemination Exploitation and Communication DEC plan outlines all initiatives to be undertaken by the Project to promote the key exploitable results of the project and to boost consumer acceptance and public awareness The DEC will be updated when necessary Tasks 62 63 T64

result.title: Methodologies for the sustainability analysis of the NET-Fuels technology
result.description: A description of the framework for sustainability assessments is presented including system boundaries reference biofuel production systems time horizon of the analysis preliminary definition of the functional units preliminary identification and selection of scenarios preliminary decision about impact categories Task 41

result.title: First dissemination, exploitation and communication report
result.description: All dissemination, exploitation and communication initiatives developed in the first phase of the project are illustrated.

category.title: Digital agenda
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development of digital technologies and the digitisation of the economy and society (known as ‘Digital transition’).

category.title: Clean air
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the clean air policy (National Emission Ceiling Directive) aiming to improve ambient air quality and tackle air pollution, to protect the environment and human health.

category.title: Artificial intelligence
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development and deployment of AI-based technologies and solutions. Projects that develop AI-tools as part of their research method are included

category.title: Climate action
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to both mitigating climate change (e.g., contributions to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions) and adapting to climate change by building resilience (e.g., regarding floods, droughts, spatial planning and better governance, adaptation to changing climate in value chains, etc.).

category.title: Biodiversity
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to Europe’s biodiversity’s path to recovery including species protection, ecosystem conservation, and habitat rehabilitation, all essential for resilience in climate adaptation and addressing ecosystem services but also environmental crime and the health-environment connection.
